item.title: Report E-2023100472
item.description:
Report E-2023100472

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-18T15:12:15+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-13
  • City: GRAND RAPIDS
  • State: MI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XGR experienced a UN1814 ConvoClean Forte release from a 2.5-gallon poly jug. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 0.25-gallons of product released to a 2’ x 2’ area of the concrete dock floor due to improper handling. Absorbents were deployed by XPO terminal personnel and worked into the impacted area by contractors. The impacted absorbents and damaged jug were then containerized into a 30-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100437
item.description:
Report E-2023100437

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-06
  • City: PHOENIX
  • State: AZ
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: RESPONDED TO AIRCRAFT BELLY DUE TO AN ODOR. UPON INSPECTION DISCOVERED TWO JERRICANS LAYING ON THEIR SIDES LEAKING CONTENTS FROM THEIR CLOSURES. PRODUCT LABELS APPLIED TO THE CONTAINERS INDICATE FLAMMABLE PICTOGRAMS AND A FLASH POINT OF 118.9F. OTHER THAN THE PICTOGRAMS THERE ARE NO ADDITIONAL DANGEROUS GOODS MARKS OR LABELS ON THE OUTER CONTAINERS. ADDITIONAL LEAKING PACKAGE TRACKING NUMBER 1Z6430970143400719.

item.title: Report E-2023100436
item.description:
Report E-2023100436

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-12
  • City: FRIDLEY
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XMP experienced a UN1993 N-Serve 24 release from a 250-gallon metal tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-cup of product released to a 2’ x 4’ area of the trailer floor due to leaking weld. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one for shipment on. The impacted tote and trailer floor were cleaned with a purple power solution and wiped clean with absorbent pads. The impacted absorbents were then containerized into a 20-gallon metal drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100434
item.description:
Report E-2023100434

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-11
  • City: DORAL
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: DURING SCREENING PROCESS OF A PREBUILT UNIT (PBE) ULD AAY07359UPS OFFERED TO UPS AIR CARGO SERVICES IN MIAMI, FLORIDA GOING TO COLOMBIA, WE DISCOVERED FIVE BOXES LOADED INSIDE THE ULD CONTAINING DANGEROUS GOODS. THERE ARE FOUR BOXES WITH LTD QTY MARKINGS CUT OUT BUT CONTENTS ARE AEROSOL PLEXI-CLEAR CLEANER. ONE ADDITIONAL BOX IS UNMARKED FROM THE OUTSIDE BUT THE INNER BOX CONTAINS A GROUND PACKAGE THAT HAD PREVIOUSLY PASSED A GROUND ACCEPTANCE AUDIT. THE BOX CONTAINS THREE GALLONS OF UN1133 ADHESIVES, PG II. THESE ARE SMALL PACKAGES CONTAINED WITHIN THE AIR CONTAINER. DANGEROUS GOODS ARE PROHIBITED IN ALL PREBUILT UNITS. AN INVESTIGATION WITH THE SHIPPER IS ONGOING.

item.description:
Report E-2023100344

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-02
  • City: MINNEAPOLIS
  • State: MN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On October 2, 2023, four (4) 55-gallon drums of UN3093 arrived without caps and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EX Environmental (EXE) to remediate the impacted site. Three of the lids were re-secured and the facility had to provide a fourth. The drums were sent back with the driver. EXE personnel deployed absorbents and absorbent pads to the ferric nitrate solution-impacted trailer interior. All spent absorbent pads and absorbents were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport to the terminal.

item.title: Report E-2023100330
item.description:
Report E-2023100330

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-10
  • City: GLENPOOL
  • State: OK
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LTU experienced a UN1791 Extract-2 release from (2) 55-gallon poly drums. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2-cups of product released to the drum lids of each drum due to loose bung caps. The released product was cleaned off the drums with absorbent rags and the caps were re-secured for shipment on. All impacted absorbent pads and PPE were containerized into a 45-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023100326
item.description:

  • City: KANSAS CITY
  • State: KS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XKC experienced a UN3266 Enrich No. 299 release from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 3-ounces of product released to the drum lid due to the drum being dropped, causing a puncture. The damaged drum was placed into a 95-gallon poly overpack. All impacted rags used to clean the release were placed into a 5-gallon poly pail. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XCF experienced a UN3084 Kleen MCT411 release from a 318-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released from the tote cap impacting the tote lid and body only. The tote was wiped down and the cap was replaced with a new vented bung. The damaged cap, impacted rags, and PPE were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage

item.title: Report I-2023090154
item.description:
Report I-2023090154

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-17T15:12:35+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-13
  • City: Sunol
  • State: RI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: CHEMICAL TRANSFER CO.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Driver got lost, drove onto a narrow rural road and could not negotiate a sharp tum causing left rear of trailer to leave road and rolled down an embankment. When the trailer overturned, it hit a small tree which had branches that entered the spill dam/ rollover protection area and hit the 3/4 inch air inlet line at the base of the Fort Valve PRD and broke the 3/4 inch stainless steel nipple for the air inlet line. There were no other package failures. At this point the cargo tank lost approximately 300 gallons, ER personnel would not allow us to stop the leak until there the tank was anchored by a recovery unit. We requested a tow truck to anchor it around 5:30 on Wed 9-13-2023, but one was never called. At approximately 7:00 PM, the incident commander decided to put off all efforts on hold until 7:30/8:00 AM the following morning due to location and darkness setting in. Due to no cell phone coverage in the area, we had requested ER personnel made all required ^ notifications to EPA, CaIOES, NRC, etc. California Highway Patrol was IC, Alameda Fire was on site, Ambulance, Fish and Wildlife, local environmental agency, the Sf Water district, etc were all onsite. At 07:30 on 9-14-23, a recovery 65 ton rotator arrived on site to secure the trailer. At approximately 8:30 we were allowed to do damage assessment on the trailer and found the source of the leak, drove a redwood plug onto it and stopped the leak. We then hooked up a 2 inch hose between the discharge line and a 70 barrel vacuum tank. By this time, since plugging was delayed, the cargo tank lost approximately 2,000 gallons of product. Tank was emptied, recovered and uprighted.

An environmental company was dispatched to remediate the spill. Upon inspection, two 5-gallon pails had released from one to two gallons of adhesive each. The two adhesive pails were placed into a 55-gallon salvage drum. The impacted stretch wrap was also placed into the salvage drum. The remaining pails were undamaged and were restacked and stretch wrapped.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: package handler in the unload notified QA admin of a damaged hazmat they had found in a trailer, explaining that the package had been found crushed under other packages. they had placed it in a lined tote. QA admin took the lined tote and brought it to the damage area, moving it to the drain mats in the incoming damaged hazmat/LQ area. in-house cleanup, awaiting disposition. DescribePack: the top of the box is crushed. the jerrican inside, which was surrounded by styrofoam peanuts, has a small crack in the top rim through which the product leaked. the staining on the top and side of the box implicates a high possibility that the package had been packed lying on its side and leaked so much during transit for this reason. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: placed in lined tote, moved to drain mats

  • Description: Prior driver delivered before this driver into tanks 4 and 5 and the vents are all manifold together. Driver put cones out. Driver stick the tanks to confirm the stick readings were 2 inches under the veeder root reading. Driver loaded 3 compartments into tank 6 with no issues. Driver loaded last compartment into tank 7. Compartment started to slow down on unloading, driver shut external valve and kept internal open. Driver cleared product hose and moved it back to tank 6. Product started to over flow out of tank 7.

item.title: Report E-2023100362
item.description:
Report E-2023100362

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-15
  • City: HELENA
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NMP experienced a customer location release of UN3098 Wheycide from a 55-gallon poly drum. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of product released to a 6' x 1' area of the trailer floor, and a 7' x 6' area of the concrete lot below due to a forklift puncture. Acid gator was deployed onto the impacted areas. The material remaining in the damaged drum was neutralized and solidified. The damaged empty drum was then containerized into a cubic yard box. All impacted absorbents were then collected into (2) 55-gallon vented poly drums. The waste was then transported to the XPO terminal located in Memphis, TN, and staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-29
  • City: WALLER
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 29, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN3265 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately two (2) cups of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. Crews deployed soda ash and absorbents to the UN3265-impacted dock and swept them in with hand tools. All spent absorbents and debris were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon super sack. LSH personnel patched and placed the damaged 55-gallon drum of product into one (1) 95-gallon drum.

  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NWR experienced a UN1791 "Dynachlor" release from a 275-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct containment and cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 200-gallons of product released to a 20' x 30' area of the concrete dock floor and a 100' x 50' area of the asphalt lot below. Absorbents and neutralizer were deployed and worked into the impacted areas. The remaining product was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. The damaged tote was then cut up and containerized along with all impacted absorbents and cleanup debris into (6) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: On September 29, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN1224 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior and loading dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Environmental Restoration, LLC (ER) to remediate the impacted site. Prior to their arrival, R+L personnel deployed granular absorbents to the impacted areas to contain the release. Crews utilized an 85-gallon overpack to contain the damaged 55-gallon drum. ER personnel worked in the previously deployed granular absorbents with hand tools. Crews then collected the previously deployed granular absorbents. All UN1224- impacted material was collected and containerized in the previously mentioned 85-gallon overpack for disposal.

item.description:
Report E-2023100305

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-28
  • City: SCHENECTADY
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 9/28/2023 a Veolia employee unloading drums from a truck into another trailer at the Veolia, Schenectady, NY 10 day intransit facility when the employee noticed that a 14 gallon fiber drum was stained and damp. The 14 gallon drum contained a 2.5 gallon glass bottle of Formic Acid With Not Less Than 5% But Less Than 10% Acid By Mass corrosive liquids. The outer container was opened and the inner container was inspected and was found to be broken and released its contents. No liquid was released from the outer packaging drum. The 14 gallon drum containing the broken glass bottle was overpacked into an 30 gallon 1H2 drum and transportation to the ultimate disposal facility was continued. The drum did not leak any amount of the corrosive liquid solution out of the outer container.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While parked at a Kwik Trip truck stop, the Veolia driver noticed liquid dripping out of the trailer. Upon investigation, he found a leaking drum with a puncture near the bottom of the container. An overpack was placed underneath the leak to contain as much of the spill as possible until the remediation crew arrived. Approximately 20 gallons of liquid leaked out of the drum. Kwik Trip contacted and emergency response company to assist with clean-up.

item.title: Report E-2023100303
item.description:
Report E-2023100303

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-14T00:31:38+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-12
  • City: AZUSA
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A Veolia driver initially picked up the drum in question on 9/5/2023 from the offeror and the trailer was used to pick up other materials on 9/12/23. The driver noticed that there was some liquid on the front of the trailer along with oily stains on the back of the trailer. Veolia personnel started to remove the drums from the trailer and identified the leaking drum which was located at the nose of the trailer. The leaking drum was a 55 gal metal drum with a pin hole leak that appeared to occur from potentially rubbing/impact against another drum during transportation which was a weak spot due to corrosion. The driver made multiple stops that day and he has stated that he did not notice any staining on the back-end of the trailer when he loaded addition drums at each stop. Also he did not notice any oily material near or around the front of the trailer during those stops. We are unsure of the duration of the spill but based on the quantity still left in the drum, roughly 5 gallons had leaked out. The drum was placed into a salvage drum and the spill clean up was completed by the Veolia in-house crew. Most of the material was contained inside the trailer with minimal amounts outside of the trailer. There was no evidence of a any spill on the ground itself.

  • Description: On September 09, 2023, at 1945 ET, Emergency Response and Training Solutions (ERTS) was contacted by Loaf'N Jug's personnel in Evanston, Wyoming regarding the release of approximately (50) gallons of Diesel Fuel (UN1202 3, III) from (1) tank truck. Contractors were dispatched to clean up the release with absorbents and the proper PPE. Upon arrival, contractors confirmed that the release was contained to asphalt and concrete. The local fire department arrived prior to the contractors and placed absorbents. The first round of absorbents were cleaned UP and containerized, then the contractors added more to confirm that all the release was absorbed and collected. All waste generated from addressing this release was containerized in (1) 55-gallon metal drum which was staged onsite in preparation for proper disposal.

item.description:

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-12T15:12:08+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-26
  • City: DAVENPORT
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 26, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2735 was punctured and released approximately fifty (50) gallons of product to the trailer floor and concrete parking lot. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from EnviroServe (ES) to remediate the impacted site. ES placed the damaged drum into one (1) 85-gallon overpack for transport and disposal. ES deployed a neutralizing agent and absorbents to the trailer floor and concrete parking lot. The crew utilized absorbent pads to wipe underneath the trailer. ES collected the spent absorbents into five (5) drums for transport and disposal. On September 28, 2023, ES returned to the site. ES utilized a combination of a neutralizer, absorbent wipes, and hand tools to remove the residue buildup generated from the original cleanup. The crew placed the spent neutralizer and absorbents into one (1) 55-gallon drum for transport and disposal. ES staged the drum onsite to be processed via R+L's normal waste stream.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On September 27, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN3098 was dropped by a forklift and released approximately five (5) gallons to the trailer interior and pavement beneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE personnel deployed poly sheeting, pH neutralizers, soda ash, granular absorbents, and pad absorbents to theUN3098-impacted areas and collected them with hand tools. TLE personnel cut out the impacted wood debris from the trailer and after collection of waste and debris flushed the trailer. All spent absorbents and debris were collected into two (2) lined 35-gallon poly drums, one with the impacted, diluted pail inside and the other with miscellaneous waste and debris, along with a lined 55-gallon poly drum containing mixed waste and cleanup debris.

  • Description: Driver arrived at customer location to fill a Dimethylformamide(DMF) tank. He verified the tank, quantity, and connection prior to starting to pump. After several moments after beginning transfer, customer employee notified driver that nothing was transferring. Driver inspected the connections and proceeded to check on the internal valve, which he closed and opened again. After doing so a cap on the rear of the trailer popped off and product started coming out of the open pipe. Driver shutdown the pump and approximately 90 gallons of DMF spilled into the customer's containment. The cause of the release was the result of a faulty outlet cap. During the investigation it was determined that there was no isolation valve installed behind the cap.

item.title: Report I-2023090135
item.description:
Report I-2023090135

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-24
  • City: Westlake
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: THE KANSAS CITY SOUTHERN RAILWAY COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 1:00 on 8/24/2023 Kansas City Southern Railway's(DBA CPKCR) Rosebluff yard in Westlake, LA reported tank car UTLX 130533 containing UN 1789, HYDROCHLORIC ACID Ieaking from the top of the car. The Environmental& Hazmat Department mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found one of the four bolts securing the liquid line four bolt blind flange primary closure not tool tight Responders vented the rail car to stop the release and tightened the four bolt flange bolt tool tight, approximately 3 full turns. Responders also found one of the nuts used to secure the all-thread bolt on the bottom spool of the liquid line was not tool tight against the spool flange. This nut could not be secured tool tight The nut was removed and replaced with another nut that was rendered tool tight to the spool flange for proper securement The removed nut was found to be rusted and had stripped threads. Atmospheric temperature was thought to have caused sufficient thermal expansion to push liquid up the liquid line and by the loose four bolt blind flange closure and/or the spool. The defective all-thread bolt on the spool was located directly below the nut that was tool tightened on the blind flange. UTLX 130533 was monitored for an additional 20 minutes to ensure that the leak had been secured, with no leaks detected. Rendering both nuts tool tight stopped the leak. The estimated release Is 1 gallon. The released commodity on the car was neutralized. Once the release was mitlgated, the car was returned to transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a'bulk' shipment aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered In this package Is not known to the carrier. This carrier

item.title: Report X-2023080424
item.description:
Report X-2023080424

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-16T18:14:40+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-03
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Chicago Central and Pacific Railroad
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 08-03-2023 A CN mechanical performing an inbound inspection of train L-57191-03 observed liquid dripping from the bottom outlet valve cap of tank car # UTLX 212943 along with a strong Ethanol type odor in the area. The employee notified the Yard Coordinator who in turn made internal emergency notifications per the CN ERP. The tank car was set out to an isolation track (WA90) for inspection by the CN Dangerous Goods Officer. A CN Dangerous Goods Officer responding to the incident. It was immediately noted upon the initial visual inspection that the BOV handle was in the "engaged" position and the BOV handle was not pinned. It was also noted that there was wetness around the threads of the BOV cap with wetness on the ballast directly below. An Ethanol type odor was also present. The BOV cap was found to be less than tool tight (could turn by hand) allowing any product collecting within the cap to leak out. Several attempts were made to dis-engage the BOV handle from the valve so it could be pinned in the closed position. These attempts were un-successful. The BOV cap was then removed to determine if the BOV was still leaking as the tank car did not drip any liquids during the DGO's inspection and attempts to dis-engage the BOV handle from the valve. Although there was standing liquid within the BOV cap, the valve itself did not leak after a 20 minute observation. The cap was then re-installed tool tight. A cable seal was utilized to secure the BOV handle in the closed (9 O'clock) position so that it may not open during transit. Home Shop decals were applied to both sides of the tank car, the BOV was red tagged (do not operate). Both the shipper and consignee were notified of the incident and were advised the tank car will require an FRA OTMA 1 prior to being released.

The CN Dangerous Goods Officer responded and observed an audible vapor leak from the manway. An attempt was made to check for loose bolts but all manway bolts were secured tightly. All notifications were made. The CN Dangerous goods Officer vented the car and opened the manway and observed damage to gasket. Gasket appeared to be over compressed and had an obvious tear where the observed leak was. The CN Dangerous Goods Officer replaced the manway gasket with a new gasket. The manway was resecured. The railcar was released onto destination.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On July 12, 2023, FRA Hazmat Inspector observed the protective housing securement pin not properly installed. Upon closer inspection, the protective housing was opened to inspect securement, the vapor valve was observed in the partially opened position. The camlock caps for vapor and liquid valve were not installed. The FRA notified the CN Dangerous Goods Officer. The CN Dangerous Goods Officer responded. Upon arrival, he also observed the protective housing pin not properly secured. Upon closer inspection, the vapor line valve was partially opened and the camlock caps were not installed. The Dangerous Goods Officer also noticed the AR placard was missing. The vapor valve was closed. The camlock caps for the vapor and liquid valves were installed. The placard on the AR side was replaced. The railcar was released onto destination.

  • Description: On 7/25/2023, personnel at CSX Russel, KY yard, reported UTLX671478, a loaded tank car of Xylenols, was observed leaking from the top of the car. The car was isolated and SASOL Chemicals was notified via CHEMTREC (report #2023-07-25-00337). Quick Response, a CSXT emergency response contractor, was dispatched to the scene and found (1) of (8) manway cover bolts less than tool tight. The manway bolts were tightened tool tight and the released Xylenols was cleaned from the top of the car. The issue identified and corrective actions were communicated to SASOL Chemicals representative Randy Shilling (832-783-6428, Randy.Shilling@us.sasol.com). Delay in report submission due to online portal would not accept.

  • Description: Denatured ethanol leaking from defective pressure relief device on tank car. Unknown amount (1 lbs) to car sides. Car crew member reported some spilling from top of car last night but TM couldn't find any evidence of spill during day. No waterways, no injuries. USE doing tank car inspection found defective PRD. PRD was found stuck in to the open position, responders were able to reset the valve. Shipper was notified of defective PRD. A transload is schedule so the empty car can move to destination for repair/inspection. All spill ethanol evaporated from the tank car body, no impacts to soil.

item.title: Report I-2023090114
item.description:
Report I-2023090114

Identified by scraper @ 2023-10-12T00:30:42+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-04-10
  • City: Caprock
  • State: NM
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: COASTAL TRANSPORT CO., INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The cargo tank motor vehicle(CTMV) was traveling on highway 380 near mile marker 200. The CTMV experienced a tire blow out on axle four, passenger side tire. The driver was unable to stop safely as the one lane each direction roadway contained no improved or paved shoulder for emergency stops. The driver was forced to travel approximately 1.5 miles at slow speed before the driver could slowly stop at a roadside pull out. The skidding tire overheated and Ignited with flames. After stopping, the driver used the on board fire extinguisher In attempt to extingulsh the fire. The flames quickly grew and ignited the product hoses slowed on the equipment tray that is mounted on the passenger side, below the cargo compartments. The fire/heat quickly melted through the aluminum shell of the cargo compartments. As the compartment shells melted through, the flammable liquid ignited. The fire consumed the cargo tank motor vehicle(truck tractor/semi-trailer) and product. The Caprock volunteer fire department contained the blaze and allowed the product to be consumed by the fire. Approximately 150 gallons of diesel fuel remained in the bottom of the compartment shell after the fire was extinguished. This product was picked up and disposed of by the local HM response vendor that was called to the scene. The vehicle wreckage was loaded onto a flatbed semi-trailer and carried away for disposal. The HM response vendor scraped and cleaned the pavement area.
